description: Eskom's total debt exceeds R420bn with significant concentration in government-guaranteed bonds. Without debt relief, debt service costs will exceed operating cash flows, threatening solvency.
Chronic fleet underperformance with Energy Availability Factor (EAF) below 60% causing Stage 6 load shedding. Multiple units on unplanned outage exceeding 18,000MW simultaneously at peak.

Coal supply security risk: Primary suppliers unable to meet contractual volumes. Stockpiles at 13 of 15 coal stations below the 20-day emergency threshold. Spot market procurement at premium pricing required.
Air quality non-compliance at 11 of 15 coal power stations. Minimum Emission Standards (MES) violations under the National Environmental Management: Air Quality Act. Potential AEL revocations.
Transmission unbundling execution risk: Establishing NTCSA as a separate entity involves complex asset separation, staff transfers and systems migration. Delay risks regulatory non-compliance.
Ageing ICT infrastructure and SCADA systems at power stations and control centres. Average system age exceeds 15 years. Cyber attack risk elevated following global utility sector incidents.
Critical skills shortage in power station engineering and artisan trades. Over 1,200 artisan vacancies across generation fleet. Retirement wave of experienced engineers in 2025-2027.
Port of Durban container terminal operating below 50% design capacity. Average vessel waiting time 6.8 days vs global benchmark of 24 hours. R42bn annual economic impact on SA exports estimated.

Cable theft and rail vandalism costing Transnet R5bn annually in direct losses plus R18bn in lost revenue. Northern Cape iron ore corridor and manganese line severely impacted. SAPS capacity insufficient.
Transnet total debt of R132bn with R28bn maturing within 12 months. Declining freight volumes and port inefficiencies pressuring debt service coverage ratios. Refinancing risk elevated.
New locomotive programme delivery delays (CRRC contract): 440 of 1,064 units still undelivered. Local content disputes. Rolling stock maintenance backlog on aging Transnet-owned fleet.
Third party rail access disruption risk: Opening freight rail to private operators may reduce Transnet revenue by 20-30% if not managed with appropriate tariff recovery and access charges.

Eskom load shedding impact: Each stage of load shedding reduces Transnet operational capacity by approximately 8%. Port cranes, rail signalling and pumping stations affected. Diesel generator costs elevated.

SAA negative equity of R5.6bn post-business rescue. Ongoing net losses threaten long-term viability. Additional government capital injection may be required if SEP process does not conclude successfully.
Fleet age and reliability risk: Average SAA fleet age 14.8 years. Multiple aircraft requiring heavy maintenance checks. Fleet availability impacting schedule reliability and customer experience.

Fuel price volatility: Jet fuel constitutes 32% of SAA operating costs. A 10% increase in jet fuel prices increases annual costs by R380m with limited hedging in place. Brent crude above $85/bbl is critical threshold.

SAA SACAA AOC compliance risk: Failure to maintain IOSA certification or meet SACAA safety directives could result in AOC suspension, grounding the airline. Current compliance adequate but resource-constrained.

Competition risk from low-cost carriers: Kulula, FlySafair and Lift have captured 52% of domestic market share since SAA's absence. Recovering market share requires substantial marketing and pricing investment.

Denel Pension Fund deficit of R2.5bn: Defined benefit obligations exceed fund assets. Company contributions deferred due to cash constraints 2019-2022 exacerbating the deficit. Actuarial recovery plan spans 15 years.

Critical skills exodus: Salary arrears 2020-2022 caused loss of 580 engineers and technical specialists. Average experience lost estimated at 18 years per departed employee. Capabilities in certain weapons systems now below critical mass.

Contract delivery risk: Rooivalk export contract 4-month delay creates R180m penalty exposure. Production capacity constraints from skills gaps and aging manufacturing equipment threaten future contract competitiveness.

Export market credibility: Multiple delivery delays and the salary crisis have damaged Denel's reputation as a reliable defence supplier. Rebuilding international market credibility requires sustained on-time delivery performance.

NCACC export compliance: Increasing complexity of international sanctions regimes requires rigorous end-user certificate verification. Risk of inadvertent export control violation with consequent criminal penalties.

Transmission entity capital requirements: NTCSA will require R180-220bn in capital investment over 10 years for grid expansion to accommodate 14,000MW of new renewable generation. Funding sources not fully committed.

Irregular expenditure legacy: R6.2bn in irregular expenditure identified in FY2021-FY2022 AGSA audits related to State Capture-era procurement. Consequence management processes slow. Legal recovery actions limited.

Rand/Dollar exchange rate risk: Aircraft leases, maintenance and fuel denominated in USD. A R1 depreciation against USD increases annual costs by approximately R120m. Limited natural hedging available.

Tariff cost-reflectivity gap: Even after NERSA 18.65% increase, tariff remains below full cost-reflective level by an estimated 8-12%. Cumulative deficit compounds annually reducing path to profitability.

Manufacturing facility condition risk: Several Denel facilities (Swartklip, Lyttleton) require major refurbishment. Deferred maintenance during financial crisis has elevated operational failure risk and safety incidents.
